column2: Ghosts.

column2: At first sight, the exterior of the house at Auteuil gave no indications of splendor, nothing one would expect from the destined residence of the magnificent Count of Monte Cristo; but this simplicity was according to the will of its master, who positively ordered nothing to be altered outside.
column3: At first sight, the exterior of the house at Auteuil gave no indications of splendor, nothing one would expect from the destined residence of the magnificent Count of Monte Cristo; but this simplicity was according to the will of its master, who positively ordered nothing to be altered outside.

column2: The splendor was within.
column3: The splendor was within.

column2: Indeed, almost before the door opened, the scene changed.
column3: Indeed, almost before the door opened, the scene changed.

column2: M. Bertuccio had outdone himself in the taste displayed in furnishing, and in the rapidity with which it was executed. It is told that the Duc d'Antin removed in a single night a whole avenue of trees that annoyed Louis XIV.; in three days M. Bertuccio planted an entirely bare court with poplars, large spreading sycamores to shade the different parts of the house, and in the foreground, instead of the usual paving-stones, half hidden by the grass, there extended a lawn but that morning laid down, and upon which the water was yet glistening.
column3: M. Bertuccio had outdone himself in the taste displayed in furnishing, and in the rapidity with which it was executed. It is told that the Duc d'Antin removed in a single night a whole avenue of trees that annoyed Louis the fourteenth.; in three days m Bertuccio planted an entirely bare court with poplars, large spreading sycamores to shade the different parts of the house, and in the foreground, instead of the usual paving stones, half hidden by the grass, there extended a lawn but that morning laid down, and upon which the water was yet glistening.

column2: For the rest, the orders had been issued by the count; he himself had given a plan to Bertuccio, marking the spot where each tree was to be planted, and the shape and extent of the lawn which was to take the place of the paving-stones.
column3: For the rest, the orders had been issued by the count; he himself had given a plan to Bertuccio, marking the spot where each tree was to be planted, and the shape and extent of the lawn which was to take the place of the paving stones.

column2: Thus the house had become unrecognizable, and Bertuccio himself declared that he scarcely knew it, encircled as it was by a framework of trees.
column3: Thus the house had become unrecognizable, and Bertuccio himself declared that he scarcely knew it, encircled as it was by a framework of trees.

column2: The overseer would not have objected, while he was about it, to have made some improvements in the garden, but the count had positively forbidden it to be touched.
column3: The overseer would not have objected, while he was about it, to have made some improvements in the garden, but the count had positively forbidden it to be touched.

column2: Bertuccio made amends, however, by loading the ante-chambers, staircases, and mantle-pieces with flowers.
column3: Bertuccio made amends, however, by loading the ante chambers, staircases, and mantle pieces with flowers.

column2: What, above all, manifested the shrewdness of the steward, and the profound science of the master, the one in carrying out the ideas of the other, was that this house which appeared only the night before so sad and gloomy, impregnated with that sickly smell one can almost fancy to be the smell of time, had in a single day acquired the aspect of life, was scented with its master's favorite perfumes, and had the very light regulated according to his wish.
column3: What, above all, manifested the shrewdness of the steward, and the profound science of the master, the one in carrying out the ideas of the other, was that this house which appeared only the night before so sad and gloomy, impregnated with that sickly smell one can almost fancy to be the smell of time, had in a single day acquired the aspect of life, was scented with its master's favorite perfumes, and had the very light regulated according to his wish.

column2: When the count arrived, he had under his touch his books and arms, his eyes rested upon his favorite pictures; his dogs, whose caresses he loved, welcomed him in the ante-chamber; the birds, whose songs delighted him, cheered him with their music; and the house, awakened from its long sleep, like the sleeping beauty in the wood, lived, sang, and bloomed like the houses we have long cherished, and in which, when we are forced to leave them, we leave a part of our souls.
column3: When the count arrived, he had under his touch his books and arms, his eyes rested upon his favorite pictures; his dogs, whose caresses he loved, welcomed him in the ante chamber; the birds, whose songs delighted him, cheered him with their music; and the house, awakened from its long sleep, like the sleeping beauty in the wood, lived, sang, and bloomed like the houses we have long cherished, and in which, when we are forced to leave them, we leave a part of our souls.

column2: The servants passed gayly along the fine court-yard; some, belonging to the kitchens, gliding down the stairs, restored but the previous day, as if they had always inhabited the house; others filling the coach-houses, where the equipages, encased and numbered, appeared to have been installed for the last fifty years; and in the stables the horses replied with neighs to the grooms, who spoke to them with much more respect than many servants pay their masters.

column2: The library was divided into two parts on either side of the wall, and contained upwards of two thousand volumes; one division was entirely devoted to novels, and even the volume which had been published but the day before was to be seen in its place in all the dignity of its red and gold binding.

column2: On the other side of the house, to match with the library, was the conservatory, ornamented with rare flowers, that bloomed in china jars; and in the midst of the greenhouse, marvellous alike to sight and smell, was a billiard-table which looked as if it had been abandoned during the past hour by players who had left the balls on the cloth.

column2: The one with a white dress and so many diamonds--the fair one.
column3: The one with a white dress and so many diamonds-the fair one.

column2: Madame Danglars?
column3: Madame Danglars?

column2: I do not know her name; but it is she, sir, it is she!
column3: I do not know her name; but it is she, sir, it is she!

column2: Whom do you mean?
column3: Whom do you mean?

column2: The woman of the garden!--she that was enciente--she who was walking while she waited for--Bertuccio stood at the open door, with his eyes starting and his hair on end.
column3: The woman of the garden!--she that was enciente-she who was walking while she waited for--Bertuccio stood at the open door, with his eyes starting and his hair on end.

column2: Waiting for whom? Bertuccio, without answering, pointed to Villefort with something of the gesture Macbeth uses to point out Banquo.
column3: Waiting for whom? Bertuccio, without answering, pointed to Villefort with something of the gesture Macbeth uses to point out Banquo.

column2: Oh, oh, he at length muttered, "do you see?"
column3: Oh, oh, he at length muttered, "do you see?"

column2: What?	What?
column3: true

column2: Who?"
column3: Who?"

column2: Him!
column3: Him!

column2: Him!--M. de Villefort, the king's attorney?	Him!--M. de Villefort, the king's attorney?
column3: false

column2: Certainly I see him."
column3: Certainly I see him."

column2: Then I did not kill him?
column3: Then I did not kill him?

column2: Really, I think you are going mad, good Bertuccio, said the count.
column3: Really, I think you are going mad, good Bertuccio, said the count.

column2: Then he is not dead?
column3: Then he is not dead?

column2: No; you see plainly he is not dead.	No; you see plainly he is not dead.
column3: true

column2: Instead of striking between the sixth and seventh left ribs, as your countrymen do, you must have struck higher or lower, and life is very tenacious in these lawyers, or rather there is no truth in anything you have told me--it was a fright of the imagination, a dream of your fancy.
column3: Instead of striking between the sixth and seventh left ribs, as your countrymen do, you must have struck higher or lower, and life is very tenacious in these lawyers, or rather there is no truth in anything you have told me-it was a fright of the imagination, a dream of your fancy.

column2: You went to sleep full of thoughts of vengeance; they weighed heavily upon your stomach; you had the nightmare--that's all.
column3: You went to sleep full of thoughts of vengeance; they weighed heavily upon your stomach; you had the nightmare-that's all.

column2: Come, calm yourself, and reckon them up--M. and Madame de Villefort, two; M. and Madame Danglars, four; M. de Chateau-Renaud, M. Debray, M. Morrel, seven; Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti, eight."
column3: Come, calm yourself, and reckon them up-M. and Madame de Villefort, two; m and Madame Danglars, four; m de Chateau Renaud, m Debray, m Morrel, seven; Major Bartolomeo Cavalcanti, eight."

column2: Eight! repeated Bertuccio.
column3: Eight! repeated Bertuccio.

column2: Stop!	Stop!
column3: true

column2: You are in a shocking hurry to be off--you forget one of my guests.
column3: You are in a shocking hurry to be off-you forget one of my guests.

column2: Lean a little to the left.
column3: Lean a little to the left.

column2: Stay! look at M. Andrea Cavalcanti, the young man in a black coat, looking at Murillo's Madonna; now he is turning." This time Bertuccio would have uttered an exclamation, had not a look from Monte Cristo silenced him.
column3: Stay! look at m Andrea Cavalcanti, the young man in a black coat, looking at Murillo's Madonna; now he is turning." This time Bertuccio would have uttered an exclamation, had not a look from Monte Cristo silenced him.

column2: Benedetto? he muttered; "fatality!"
column3: Benedetto? he muttered; "fatality!"

column2: Half-past six o'clock has just struck, M. Bertuccio, said the count severely; "I ordered dinner at that hour, and I do not like to wait;" and he returned to his guests, while Bertuccio, leaning against the wall, succeeded in reaching the dining-room.
column3: Half past six o'clock has just struck, m Bertuccio, said the count severely; "I ordered dinner at that hour, and I do not like to wait;" and he returned to his guests, while Bertuccio, leaning against the wall, succeeded in reaching the dining room.

column2: Five minutes afterwards the doors of the drawing-room were thrown open, and Bertuccio appearing said, with a violent effort, "The dinner waits."
column3: Five minutes afterwards the doors of the drawing room were thrown open, and Bertuccio appearing said, with a violent effort, "The dinner waits."

column2: The Count of Monte Cristo offered his arm to Madame de Villefort.
column3: The Count of Monte Cristo offered his arm to Madame de Villefort.

column2: M. de Villefort, he said, "will you conduct the Baroness Danglars?"
column3: M. de Villefort, he said, "will you conduct the Baroness Danglars?"

column2: Villefort complied, and they passed on to the dining-room.
column3: Villefort complied, and they passed on to the dining room.
